title: The Prevalence of Political Discourse in Non-Political Blogs

author: Sean A. Munson, Department of Human Centered Design and Engineering, University of Washington

segmentation: Morning my name is Sean Munson.
As winter said and I'll be presenting some joint work with Paul Resnik.
So just want to start with a brief discussion of some of our motivations for this work.
There's been a lot of concern raised about him.

If Leanne Island political discourse Michael reviewed some of it, I'm not going to belabor it, but we see things such as political bloggers linking primarily to similarly minded individuals when they link.
High levels of agreement in comment threads on blogs, including political blogs and challenge aversion prevalent among peoples.
Preferences for political news aggregators.
But I have to ask, when we do this work and we look at political spaces.
Isn't it maybe like looking for diverse opinions at a political rally right?
There isn't really a lot of diversity here.
Yeah, there are some references to the other side.
You might hear some disagreements, but these spaces are not really the height of political discourse.
And when there is a space for other opinions, it's often in this walled off free speech zone.
So maybe we should be looking at.
Where else?
But we know from a long tradition in political sociology from Harbor, Mason, Putnam and others, that civic organizations such as service clubs.
Or clubs such as bowling leagues?
Or spaces like coffee shops or bars or diverse people come together in politics comes up sometimes.

And if you actually look at this last photo, which I found just searching Flickr for photos of bars under a Creative Commons license, they're actually watching President Obama's annual state of the Union address.
If reading the comment thread they were talking about wow, I had no idea that my neighbors had these political opinions until I was there for the state of the Union.
And when people come together for these other reasons, they may be more politically diverse.
They haven't sought out like minded political individuals.
They sought out people to do service activities with or to go bowling with.
And then they may listen and frame their arguments to protect these existing relationships that they have.
But there's also a chance avoid political discussion or disagreement for fear of damaging those relationships, so it could go either way here.
I and offline we see both happening and in on line settings.
It may be even easier to filter out the disagreeable points of view.
When they do come up you can just delete them or censor them or move them to another channel, right?
It's a lot easier to navigate to a different website to make a reaction than to leave the bar and go next door somewhere else.
There are already some encouraging signs that political discussion is not taboo in non political spaces on line.
So across the Twitter work we've seen discussion of political candidates by Twitter users.
8% of US adults posted political content to a social network site during the 2010 midterm elections, and 11% discovered for whom at least one of their friends voted.
And people say they encounter cross cutting political discussion online but not in online political sites in other spaces.
So far, study wanted to look at how prevalent or political blogs or political posts in non political blogs.
What is the distribution of political blog posts across different categories of blogs?
And if and when readers do encounter not political content on non political spaces, do they treat them as taboo or do they engage and actually respond?
So I want to start by covering a bit about our sample of logs.
Which we generated by pulling.
Blogger.com's recently updated list from 6 to 20 January 2008.
The standards about 24,000 blogs we kept only blogs that had at least five posts were written in English and had existed since at least the end of August.
In the previous year.
We then inspected the blogs and illuminated spam blogs and blogs are only partially in English.
Some of this was automated and some of this was with just opening up blogs.
And that God is down about 8000.
We then ported coded post as political or nonpolitical.
Using a combination of human coding, an automated approaches and illuminated additional spam and partially English blogs that we found while we were doing that coding.
Which got us down to just another 8700 logs in about 2.3 million posts.
So a little bit more about how we classified the posts.
We used a very broad definition of political when you were looking for political posts.
Any mention of public policy campaigns, elected or appointed officials, and we didn't restrict this US politics.
So if it was politics anywhere in the world, it counted.
We, and that's mostly me categorize about 7000 persons, political or not.
We oversampled political posts and with a second coder who looked at a subset and the right of agreement was very high.

We use these coded post to train a multinomial naive Bayes classifier and classified the remaining 2.3 million posts an found about 200,000 political posts and about 2.1 million non political posts in this set.
But there's a simple.
So if we estimate prevalence, we can't just do a simple tally.
This is problematic.

You can overestimate the percentage of political blogs on blogs with few political posts, and we can underestimate it on blogs or political, most of the time just because of the false positive and false negative rates.
So to illustrate, consider A blog that is always political, right?
So every post on it is about politics, well, are false, negative rate means that about 12.6% of those will actually come out as negative as not political.
And if we consider A blog that is never political.

The false positive rate of our classifier means that about half a percent of those will show up as political, and when we're trying to look at very small amounts of political posts on these non political blogs, that's a bit problematic.
Fortunately, medical statistics has an approach for handling this, so we come up with revised estimates for prevalence based on our initial estimates and the false positive false negative rates.
We also wanted to categorise blogs beyond simply what percentage of the posts on them are political or not.
So we looked at seven categories, diary, hobby and fan, professional and sales, politics, religion, civic and issue, health and Wellness and ethnic and cultural.
We then put each block on Mechanical Turk so it was loaded in an iframe.
People could look at it and see the blog.
If for some reason the blog had been deleted.
Since we simply showed them a text file of the most recent post from that blog.
And then we use for at least five categorizations per blog, ran it through, they get another label tool, and we checked the outcomes of that against ratings from the research team.
Kappa was pretty decent.
There's a lot of logs that were kind of in between categories, and that made it difficult to get a great level of agreement.
We also coded comment threads, so we started with about 250 threads, got down to 244 because some turned out to be spam or the only comments on them were spam.
Looked at for the post was it political writer?

We actually coding a post that we want to and it was it all political or was it about other things as well so someone could be talking about a long story about their daughters health battle, throw in a sentence about how they wish they had better health care and maybe Obamacare will take care of that or it won't.
And then we also looked at the comments and said are they spam?
Are people engaged in the political content of the post?
Did they agree, disagree or none of the above with the post author and or did they call it out as taboo and again, very high level of agree?
Here.
Alright.
So results which I'm going to talk about in kind of those three questions that I posed originally, so overall prevalence, prevalence by category and engage.
So first overall.
Devilance so this graph?

We've got the blogs and this is kind of a log scale note on the left and on the right we have a cumulative percentage of the blogs and the percentage of the posts according to the revised estimate that our political and so yes, you can see that the vast majority of logs are political.
A very small amount of the time.
So it's really just.
Huge numbers are there in the non political side, but then there's this kind of gradual about of more and more political.
Another way to look at it, which I actually found.
More useful for kind of how I think about the problem is by the number of political posts.
Where are they coming from?
So again, this is by prevalence on the bottom and the number of political posts.
Again, a log scale on the left and the cumulative percent on the right, and we find out about 25% of the political blog posts come from blogs to talk about politics.
Less than 20% of the time.
So 1/4 of the political discussion is happening in non political spaces that are pretty clearly non political.
One in five at most of the posts about politics.

And this is a little bit time sensitive, so if we plot these political posts from the non political blogs on a calendar, you can see there's kind of a speak a spike on US Election Day quickly looking a little of those posts or things like I voted.
Go vote.
So they're very kind of just quick mentions or they're actually some of them are quite lengthy discussions of.

Here's how I decided how to vote on this candidate, and there's some in the lead up of people asking advice of what to vote for.
